Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Design, Analysis and Implementation of Social Interactions in Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Cognitive radio is an efficient approach to access frequency spectrum. The performance of cognitive radio networks is substantially determined by the information on spectrum occupancies. Experiments have demonstrated the temporal and spatial correlations of spectrum availability, which is of key importance in the design and analysis of cognitive radio networks. Motivated by the observation, this research studies the social interaction mechanism for secondary users to fully exploit the correlations. A recommendation mechanism is useful for secondary users to share correlated information about the spectrum. Collaborative filtering can enhance the capability of better learning the spectrum situations. For better understand and assist the design, analysis is conducted for the social interaction mechanism, based on powerful tools in social networks, such as master equation, mean filed dynamics and epidemic propagation. Continuum model, such as partial differential equations for diffusions, is also employed as the limit case of discrete cognitive radio networks. Beacon based and packet based mechanisms are used for the recommendation protocols. A 100-node hardware cognitive radio network testbed is built to demonstrate the proposed mechanisms, algorithms and protocols. The research involves aspects of wireless communications, networking, artificial intelligence and physics; thus the inter-disciplinary essence of the research also lends itself to cross-disciplinary education. New courses are devised, which involve the topics of cognitive radio networks, machine learning and image processing. This project also attracts traditionally underrepresented groups, as well as outreach high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In contrast to traditional wireless communication systems, one of the distinguishing features of cognitive radio systems is that the cognitive radio devices are typically equipped with powerful sensing and computation machineries. Hence they are capable of cognizing the spectrum environment via spectrum sensing and making intelligent decisions. A large cognitive radio network can be modeled as a society in which many intelligent secondary users interact with each other and perform various social behaviors. Each cognitive radio agent can be considered as a person, which can think (using computation devices), feel (using sensing devices) and speak (using wireless communication devices). They can exchange experiences and knowledges about the wireless spectrum, which is similar to the knowledge and social behavior propagation in real society. Hence, this project focuses on the social network modeling of cognitive radio networks, by analyzing the interaction dynamics and designing efficient communication protocols. 

The main intellectual merit outcome of this project includes

1. Belief propagation, which is similar to rumor spreading in public society, has been applied in the collaborative spectrum sensing within the framework of quickest detection. With this approach, the cognitive radio users can collaborate to sense the spectrum activities in the environment.

2. The mutual interactions of different cognitive radio agents have been studied in the context the futures spectrum market. It is assumed that users can predetermine their wireless spectrum usage and purchase futures options in advance. Then, the pricing mechanism have been studied with the swarm impact of user interactions.

3. The social behavior propagation has been studied in cognitive radio networks. It is assumed that the users can exchange their knowledges about the wireless spectrum. Then, the propagations of good knowledge and false ones within the network have been studied using the mathematical tools used for epidemic propagation. It is found that the knowledge propagation in cognitive radio can be described using the same tool as the epidemic propagation.

4. The social and psychological factors in the pricing of wireless communications have been studied. Through a social survey with hundreds of people, various significant factors such as political orientation play important roles in the willingness to pay for a faster Internet.

The broader impact outcome of this project include

1. The project provided opportunities of research in the context of cognitive radio. Substantial results, e.g., the spectrum futures market and the integration of quickest detecton and belief propagation, have been achieved. Moreover, some results in the research have been used in the course development related to wireless communications. 

2. The project has provided tutorials to high school students, particularly on the applications of Matlab in Engineering. Mr. Emmanuel Gyebison, an African American, has participated in the tutotrial, which is very helpful for his future career path.

3. PhD students have intensively been involved in the research. Their skills of carrying our research and writing reports/papers have been substantially improved.
